etymologies: Middle English (denoting a floor of a building, platform, or stopping place): shortening of Old French estage ‘dwelling’, based on Latin stare ‘to stand’. Current senses of the verb date from the early 17th century

definitions: a point, period, or step in a process or development

examples.text: there is no need at this stage to give explicit details
I was in the early stages of pregnancy

shortDefinitions: point, period, or step in process or development

definitions: a section of a journey or race

examples.text: the final stage of the journey is made by taxi

definitions: each of two or more sections of a rocket or spacecraft that have their own engines and are jettisoned in turn when their propellant is exhausted.
shortDefinitions: each of two or more sections of rocket or spacecraft that have their own engines

definitions: a specified part of a circuit, typically one consisting of a single amplifying transistor or valve with the associated equipment

examples.text: a series resistance between the headphones and the output stage

definitions: a raised floor or platform, typically in a theater, on which actors, entertainers, or speakers perform

examples.text: there are only two characters on stage

shortDefinitions: raised floor or platform on which actors perform

examples.text: I've always wanted to go on the stage

definitions: a scene of action or forum of debate, especially in a particular political context

examples.text: Argentina is playing a leading role on the international stage

shortDefinitions: scene of action or forum of debate

definitions: a floor or level of a building or structure

examples.text: the upper stage was added in the 17th century

shortDefinitions: floor or level of building or structure

definitions: (on a microscope) a raised and usually movable plate on which a slide or object is placed for examination.
shortDefinitions: (on microscope) raised and usually movable plate on which slide or object is placed for examination

definitions: (in chronostratigraphy) a range of strata corresponding to an age in time, forming a subdivision of a series
shortDefinitions: (in chronostratigraphy) range of strata corresponding to age in time

definitions: (in paleoclimatology) a period of time marked by a characteristic climate
shortDefinitions: (in palaeoclimatology) period of time marked by characteristic climate

definitions: present a performance of (a play or other show)

examples.text: the show is being staged at the Goodspeed Opera House

definitions: (of a person or group) organize and participate in (a public event)

examples.text: UDF supporters staged a demonstration in Sofia

definitions: cause (something dramatic or unexpected) to happen

examples.text: the President's attempt to stage a comeback
the dollar staged a partial recovery

shortDefinitions: cause something dramatic or unexpected to happen

definitions: style or furnish (a property for sale) in such a way as to enhance its attractiveness to potential buyers

examples.text: once we've staged the house, we bring in our photographer

shortDefinitions: style or furnish property for sale to enhance attractiveness to buyers

definitions: diagnose or classify (a disease or patient) as having reached a particular stage in the expected progression of the disease

examples.text: cancer of the prostate is staged by the way it feels on rectal exam

shortDefinitions: diagnose or classify disease or patient as having reached particular stage in expected progression of disease
